title: Erdős Problem #1008: C₄-Free Subgraphs
description: Does every graph with m edges contain a C₄-free subgraph with ≫ m^{2/3} edges? Yes, proved by Conlon-Fox-Sudakov (2014). The exponent 2/3 is optimal, as shown by Folkman's counterexample K_{n,n²}.

overview.historicalContext: Originally asked by Bollobás and Erdős at the Tihany graph theory colloquium with exponent 3/4. Folkman disproved this using K_{n,n²}: it has n³ edges but every C₄-free subgraph has only O(n²) edges. Erdős revised the conjecture to exponent 2/3 in 1971, noting that 1/2 is trivial. He mentioned Szemerédi proved it but gave no reference.
overview.problemStatement: Does every graph with m edges contain a subgraph with ≫ m^{2/3} edges which contains no C₄ (4-cycle)?
overview.proofStrategy: Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov (2014) proved the result using dependent random choice and the Kővári–Sós–Turán theorem. The idea is to carefully select a subgraph that avoids 4-cycles while retaining many edges. A simpler proof was later given by Hunter in the problem's comments.
keyInsights: C₄ = K_{2,2}, so C₄-free graphs avoid complete bipartite subgraphs
The trivial bound m^{1/2} follows from Kővári–Sós–Turán
Folkman's K_{n,n²} shows m^{3/4} is impossible
The exponent 2/3 is optimal and achievable

conclusion.summary: Every graph with m edges contains a C₄-free subgraph with Ω(m^{2/3}) edges. The exponent 2/3 is optimal, matching Folkman's lower bound from K_{n,n²}.
conclusion.implications: This result fits into the broader Zarankiewicz problem: understanding the maximum edges in K_{s,t}-free graphs. The technique of finding large forbidden-subgraph-free subgraphs has applications in combinatorics and theoretical computer science.
openQuestions: Optimal constants in the Ω(m^{2/3}) bound
Algorithmic versions: can we efficiently find such subgraphs?
Extensions to other forbidden subgraphs beyond complete bipartite graphs
